title: How to Repartition an SD Card

steps.title: Insert your SD card or SD card adaptor into an available USB drive on your Windows computer.
steps.content: Insert your SD card or SD card adaptor into an available USB drive on your Windows computer.

steps.title: Click on “Start” and select “Control Panel.
steps.content: Click on “Start” and select “Control Panel. ” The Control Panel window will display on-screen.

steps.title: Click on “System and Security,” then select “Administrative Tools.
steps.content: Click on “System and Security,” then select “Administrative Tools. ”

steps.title: Click on “Computer Management.
steps.content: Click on “Computer Management. ” The application will launch and display on-screen.

steps.title: Click on “Disk Management” in the left pane under Storage.
steps.content: Click on “Disk Management” in the left pane under Storage.

steps.title: Right-click on the name of your SD card and select “New Simple Volume.
steps.content: Right-click on the name of your SD card and select “New Simple Volume. ”

steps.title: Click on “Next” in the New Simple Volume Wizard that displays on-screen.
steps.content: Click on “Next” in the New Simple Volume Wizard that displays on-screen.

steps.title: Type the desired size of your partition, then click “Next.
steps.content: Type the desired size of your partition, then click “Next. ”

steps.title: Choose a drive letter to identify your partition, then click “Next.
steps.content: Choose a drive letter to identify your partition, then click “Next. ”

steps.title: Indicate whether you want to format your new partition, then click “Next.
steps.content: Indicate whether you want to format your new partition, then click “Next. ”

steps.title: Click on “Finish.
steps.content: Click on “Finish. ” Your SD card will now be partitioned. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Insert your SD card or SD card adaptor into an available USB drive on your Mac computer.
steps.content: Insert your SD card or SD card adaptor into an available USB drive on your Mac computer.

steps.title: Open the Applications folder, then click on “Utilities.
steps.content: Open the Applications folder, then click on “Utilities. ”

steps.title: Click on “Disk Utility.
steps.content: Click on “Disk Utility. ”

steps.title: Click on the name of your SD card in the left sidebar of Disk Utility.
steps.content: Click on the name of your SD card in the left sidebar of Disk Utility.

steps.title: Click on “Partition” at the top of Disk Utility.
steps.content: Click on “Partition” at the top of Disk Utility.

steps.title: Click on the dropdown menu below “Volume Scheme,” and select the number of partitions you want on your SD card.
steps.content: Click on the dropdown menu below “Volume Scheme,” and select the number of partitions you want on your SD card.

steps.title: Click on each partition, and select a name, format, and size for each subsequent partition.
steps.content: Click on each partition, and select a name, format, and size for each subsequent partition. If you want to use your SD card as a startup disk, click on “Options,” and select “GUID Partition Table.”

steps.title: Click on “Apply.
steps.content: Click on “Apply. ” Your SD card will now be partitioned.

steps.title: Verify that the SD card you want partitioned is installed inside your Android device.
steps.content: Verify that the SD card you want partitioned is installed inside your Android device.

steps.title: Navigate to Google Play Store on your Android device.
steps.content: Navigate to Google Play Store on your Android device.

steps.title: Search for and download the ROM Manager application by ClockworkMod.
steps.content: Search for and download the ROM Manager application by ClockworkMod.

steps.title: Launch the ROM Manager app after installation is complete.
steps.content: Launch the ROM Manager app after installation is complete.

steps.title: Tap on “Partition SD Card.
steps.content: Tap on “Partition SD Card. ”

steps.title: Select the desired size of your partition next to “Ext Size.
steps.content: Select the desired size of your partition next to “Ext Size. ”

steps.title: Select a value next to “Swap Size,” if desired.
steps.content: Select a value next to “Swap Size,” if desired. Swap size is the amount of megabytes that can be used to cache memory to help free up RAM for other programs.

steps.title: Tap on “OK.
steps.content: Tap on “OK. ” Your Android device will enter recovery mode, and partition your SD card.

steps.title: Select the option to reboot your device at the prompt.
steps.content: Select the option to reboot your device at the prompt. Your SD card will now be partitioned. [2] X Research source
